quotes.topic_title: Founder tradeoff: investing in process vs people
quotes.text: The first thing is introspection. What do you believe in, really?
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Frames the process-vs-people decision as starting with self-awareness rather than copying external playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: Founder tradeoff: investing in process vs people
quotes.text: What do you believe in, and what do the people around you believe in, and how can you be a coherent leader?
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Offers a practical alignment check: your beliefs, your team’s beliefs, and whether your leadership is consistent.

quotes.topic_title: Founder tradeoff: investing in process vs people
quotes.text: You can nudge yourself a little bit away from your happy plate, but you're not going to go super far.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A counterintuitive constraint: meaningful change is incremental, so design leadership evolution around realistic shifts.

quotes.topic_title: Founder tradeoff: investing in process vs people
quotes.text: You're not going to go from like a process-driven meritocratic, X, Y, Z person all the way to like I'm going to start a collectivist company where everything is sort of a consensus decision to do that. You're not going to do that.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Warns founders against overcorrecting into an incompatible operating model; choose approaches that fit your core style.

quotes.topic_title: Founder tradeoff: investing in process vs people
quotes.text: But I think it starts with self-awareness and then that's how people form their authentic leadership vibe, and then they flex a little bit and then they embrace other perspectives.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Provides a simple methodology for leadership growth: self-awareness → authenticity → small flexes → perspective-taking.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: my goal here is to help you get better at the craft of building and growing products.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames product work as a learnable craft, encouraging continuous improvement rather than relying on innate talent or rigid playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We chat about what differentiates the highest performing product teams from less well performing product teams, what it takes to create real change within a company, why you should be skeptical of frameworks and tools that you read about online, why all underperforming teams fail in similar ways but high performing teams succeed in many different ways, and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a contrarian mental model: failure modes converge while success patterns diverge—plus a caution to treat popular frameworks skeptically.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: With one API, your team can add over 150 HR, ATS, accounting, ticketing, and CRM integrations right into your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example/data point of using a unified API to reduce integration overhead and accelerate shipping.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You can get your first integration into production in a matter of days and save countless weeks building custom integrations, letting you get back to building your core product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable velocity insight: buy/standardize integrations to reclaim engineering time for core product work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Merge's unified API can remove this blocker from your roadmap.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Merge read)
quotes.context: Frames integrations as a roadmap blocker and positions a unified API as a direct way to eliminate that constraint on product velocity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With one API, your team can add over 150 HR, ATS, accounting, ticketing, and CRM integrations right into your product.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Merge read)
quotes.context: A concrete scale example that highlights how standardizing integrations can massively expand capability without bespoke builds.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can get your first integration into production in a matter of days and save countless weeks building custom integrations, letting you get back to building your core product.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Merge read)
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization guidance: buy/standardize integrations to reclaim engineering time for differentiated core product work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to wasted time building internal tools, or trying to run your experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo read)
quotes.context: A cautionary observation about hidden costs when experimentation tooling doesn’t fit the team’s stack, pushing teams into inefficient workarounds.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic click-through metrics, and then set you to North Star metrics, like activation, retention, subscriptions, and payments,
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo read)
quotes.context: Encourages a methodology shift from shallow metrics to North Star outcomes that better reflect real product value.

quotes.topic_title: Warm-up: names, Twitter handle, and music
quotes.text: Yeah, John Cuttlefish. There is this, I learned yesterday, there's a DJ, a famous DJ called Jon Cutler without the H, so I don't know if are people into house music knew that.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A specific example of identity/name confusion that can happen publicly (e.g., online presence) and how unexpected associations emerge.

quotes.topic_title: Warm-up: names, Twitter handle, and music
quotes.text: Yeah, I think usually it just, like most Johns, it forms into Cutler or JC or something like that, but just John is good, yeah, for now, or Cuttlefish, you could just call me Cuttlefish. That'd be fine.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A practical, low-friction approach to naming/identity—accepting multiple labels and reducing social awkwardness around formality.

quotes.topic_title: Warm-up: names, Twitter handle, and music
quotes.text: In fact, the person yesterday who reached out over Twitter said, "Dude, I don't know what you're doing now in your career, but I really like your earlier work."
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A concrete anecdote showing how people may project assumptions onto you based on name/brand collisions, especially on social platforms.

quotes.topic_title: Warm-up: names, Twitter handle, and music
quotes.text: I wrote songs and played rock music and stuff, not like a house DJ.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A clarifying contrast that highlights how similar labels ("music") can mask very different skill sets and identities.

quotes.topic_title: Setting expectations: a long, deep conversation
quotes.text: I just have a feeling this is going to be one of the longest episodes we've done because there's so much I want to ask you, and there's so much interesting stuff that you've had access to and that I think that you can share.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets an expectation-setting tactic: explicitly frame the scope and depth up front to align on a “marathon” conversation.

quotes.topic_title: Setting expectations: a long, deep conversation
quotes.text: I'm on vacation now between jobs, so this is the highlight of my day. We can go all day if you want.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Highlights how timing and context (between roles) can create unusually open, high-signal conversations and knowledge-sharing opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Setting expectations: a long, deep conversation
quotes.text: what's most interesting about it is it give you access to an incredible number of product teams and product managers, unlike anything else I've seen or any other role I've seen before.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to a distinctive vantage point—cross-team exposure—as a powerful way to spot patterns in high-performing product organizations.

quotes.topic_title: John’s Amplitude role: product evangelist in practice
quotes.text: basically my job was to wake up every morning and do things that would overlap Amplitude the product, but then help uplevel our customers, sort of uplevel the broader product community.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A clear definition of an evangelist role as simultaneously serving the product and raising the capability of the broader ecosystem.

quotes.topic_title: John’s Amplitude role: product evangelist in practice
quotes.text: I call them current customers and future customers. That's how I woke up every day, I'm either talking to a current customer, I'm talking to a future customer.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A simple segmentation mental model for prioritizing time and tailoring help based on where someone is in the adoption journey.

quotes.topic_title: John’s Amplitude role: product evangelist in practice
quotes.text: I had these things called product therapy sessions when I would just wake up in the morning and just kind of soak in whatever problem people were having for the day.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable practice for uncovering real customer/team pain and building trust through open-ended problem intake.

quotes.topic_title: John’s Amplitude role: product evangelist in practice
quotes.text: I did meet with hundreds and hundreds of people and did workshops for thousands and thousands of people and talks for more than that, tens of thousands, really, in terms of the talks.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A specific scale example that illustrates how leverage can come from education, coaching, and community-facing work.

quotes.topic_title: John’s Amplitude role: product evangelist in practice
quotes.text: an evangelist is there to help uplevel the world with trusted expertise
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of the core purpose of evangelism as credibility-building through genuinely useful expertise.

quotes.topic_title: Workshops at scale and community evangelism model
quotes.text: At Amplitude, especially the way that we saw that is companies put money in and that sort of creates skin in the game. They're really paying you less for the professional services and more for the accountability and the access to the expertise.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Reframes professional services as a mechanism for commitment and accountability rather than just deliverables.

quotes.topic_title: Workshops at scale and community evangelism model
quotes.text: So, I would joke with Jenna from that team that maybe we should have monetized all these workshops. I know Gibb and other people, they're charging a good chunk for North Star workshops and here we were just kind of doing them for free.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Highlights a strategic tradeoff between free value delivery and monetizing high-demand workshops.

quotes.topic_title: Workshops at scale and community evangelism model
quotes.text: And I would put in my newsletter, "Hey, anyone want a workshop?" And then suddenly, our sales team, we had to grapple with what are we going to do with these 120 leads, how are we going to work with them.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Concrete example of how scaling “free workshops” can create real operational and pipeline-management challenges.

quotes.topic_title: Workshops at scale and community evangelism model
quotes.text: but ultimately, I think you shouldn't rely on individual people. You should think of evangelists as almost like concentric circles of your community and some people who just happen to have more expertise.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Introduces a scalable community evangelism model that avoids single points of failure.

quotes.topic_title: Workshops at scale and community evangelism model
quotes.text: everyone's an advocate. Everyone's a potential evangelist. It's just that there's only so many hours in the day.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Actionable mindset shift: distribute evangelism across the org rather than centralizing it in one role.

quotes.topic_title: How many teams: volume of coaching and talks
quotes.text: So, I think I did it... There might have been over the four years, maybe 800 one-on-ones, individual leader one-on-ones.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Concrete scale data point that signals how much direct leadership coaching informed his perspective across many contexts.

quotes.topic_title: How many teams: volume of coaching and talks
quotes.text: I'm thinking it was at the peak, it was in one year's 150 workshops and then overlapped in the next year, then between 200, but mostly the average maybe let's say three or 400 workshops, a hundred a year. It's heavy.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Specific volume metrics that quantify the intensity and breadth of workshop-based coaching exposure.

quotes.topic_title: How many teams: volume of coaching and talks
quotes.text: I tried to total, I exported all my Google Calendar invites, I tried to categorize all them at some point, but really also you have to think about it is that what we did with the North Star Playbook, it was truly a team effort at Amplitude.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Practical method for auditing your own work (calendar export/categorization) plus a reminder that impactful playbooks are built collaboratively.

quotes.topic_title: How many teams: volume of coaching and talks
quotes.text: she pulled together this workshop and she came up with these three games of product which is a really tricky and cool way to describe how your North Star inputs and North Star should be, and it started this ball rolling, and then they wrote a blog post about it.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Example of a lightweight framework (“three games of product”) emerging from real customer pressure and then being codified into reusable content.

quotes.topic_title: How Amplitude playbooks were built (not magic)
quotes.text: We started to have our, I think it was Sandhya who needed to like, we had three days to go in to close a customer and they were looking for us for trusted expertise, and she pulled together this workshop and she came up with these three games of product which is a really tricky and cool way to describe how your North Star inputs and North Star should be, and it started this ball rolling, and then they wrote a blog post about it.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Shows how a practical, time-boxed customer need can catalyze a reusable framework (“three games of product”) that later becomes cornerstone content.

quotes.topic_title: How Amplitude playbooks were built (not magic)
quotes.text: But yeah, the whole point is that a lot of this stuff was evolved over time. It wasn't just some snap marketing campaign to do it.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Counters the assumption that high-impact playbooks are primarily marketing outputs, emphasizing iterative evolution from real work.

quotes.topic_title: How Amplitude playbooks were built (not magic)
quotes.text: I did some research and our CS team developed 110-page bulk of research from working directly with customers around retention engagement, then we had a PM and a great content writer, Archana, zero in and kind of make it palatable, then we did ARC for it.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A concrete example of a cross-functional process (CS research → PM + writer synthesis → review) for turning customer work into scalable playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: How Amplitude playbooks were built (not magic)
quotes.text: It's a company filled with passionate experts of these things, and it was like tested, iterated, tested, iterated, expanded, tested, put into motion, put into practice, and that's how you create these kind of franchise cornerstone pieces of content for your company. You don't just snap your fingers one day.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology: treat playbooks as products—test and iterate in practice until they earn “cornerstone” status.

quotes.topic_title: Leaving Amplitude: gratitude, intensity, and lessons
quotes.text: In fact, if I had been a paid consultant, I never would've been able to do that.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive career/operating model: embedded roles can create broader, higher-variance exposure than traditional consulting.

quotes.topic_title: Leaving Amplitude: gratitude, intensity, and lessons
quotes.text: Another thing too is that there's this sort of selection bias. If you're a consultant, people come to you to work with you, but often I just had to talk to whatever team wanted access to expertise at Amplitude, not necessarily me.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Offers a practical mental model (selection bias) for why advice and “best practices” can be skewed by who opts in to seek help.

quotes.topic_title: Leaving Amplitude: gratitude, intensity, and lessons
quotes.text: One, you are talking to a bunch of different companies, achieving the almost similar results in very, very different ways.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Reinforces an actionable lesson for practitioners: don’t copy tactics—similar outcomes can come from very different behaviors and contexts.

quotes.topic_title: Leaving Amplitude: gratitude, intensity, and lessons
quotes.text: You would see the pandemic kick in and then you would talk to 50 companies that were dealing with the ramifications of it.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A concrete example/data point showing the value of comparative context across many organizations facing the same shock.

quotes.topic_title: Leaving Amplitude: gratitude, intensity, and lessons
quotes.text: There was not one jaded person in the room.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A memorable observation about regional/cultural differences in team mindset that can shape how you lead, coach, and design enablement.

quotes.topic_title: Next chapter: moving to Toast and going internal
quotes.text: But I think that what I realized over the course of these four years is that I wanted to pivot back to help put most of my energy into helping my own company.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A practical career/product-ops lesson about focusing impact by concentrating effort internally rather than spreading it across many external contexts.

quotes.topic_title: Next chapter: moving to Toast and going internal
quotes.text: They're growing super fast, so the numbers are in the hundreds of everything or in the thousands of everything, and they're not just the POS business.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A concrete scaling datapoint that signals the operational complexity and coordination challenges of hypergrowth product organizations.

quotes.topic_title: Next chapter: moving to Toast and going internal
quotes.text: Amplitude is a super horizontal, if you think about it, it's almost like a diagonal, and so it made your head spin, and I kind of wanted to go back to a vertical SaaS.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A memorable mental model (“horizontal… almost like a diagonal”) contrasting horizontal platforms vs. vertical SaaS focus and the cognitive load each creates.

quotes.topic_title: Next chapter: moving to Toast and going internal
quotes.text: And so, I'll be helping enable product teams and sort of doing what I was doing, but within a company as well.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: An actionable operating model: shifting from external enablement to internal enablement to drive change through embedded support.

quotes.topic_title: Why John’s writing embraces mess over prescriptions
quotes.text: And then the context free advice was obviously I noticed more and more that people trying to put tools in play out of context sometimes had worse effects than them just not doing it at all to do that.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A cautionary, actionable principle: applying “best practices” without context can actively harm outcomes, so teams should adapt tools to their environment.

quotes.topic_title: Why John’s writing embraces mess over prescriptions
quotes.text: So, I thought about the angle, about wanted to explore three things. I think the first one is this idea we do work in these complex adaptive systems, and so I really went deep in that particular area.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A clear framing for his methodology: treat product work as a complex adaptive system rather than a linear, prescriptive process.

quotes.topic_title: Why John’s writing embraces mess over prescriptions
quotes.text: So, we work in environments. There's lots of things that are interdependent on each other. We don't work in closed systems.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A memorable systems-thinking reminder that decisions and outcomes are shaped by interdependencies beyond the team’s immediate control.

quotes.topic_title: Why John’s writing embraces mess over prescriptions
quotes.text: How even though we know that if you try to do less at once, you'll be more effective, teams routinely just load themself up with work?
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that challenges “just prioritize” advice and points to deeper incentives and dynamics behind chronic overload.

quotes.topic_title: Why John’s writing embraces mess over prescriptions
quotes.text: Every company has these three pillars, and it seems really smart for the CEO to have this really clear three pillars, but then everyone walks away from the meeting and be like, "I don't know what we're with doing."
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A concrete example of how seemingly crisp strategy artifacts can still fail to create shared understanding or alignment in practice.

quotes.topic_title: What differentiates the highest-performing product teams
quotes.text: he calls it the reverse Anna Karenina principle. In Anna Karenina, Tolstoy is basically the like, "The dysfunctional families are all different and the happy families are the same," and what he said is it's the reverse of that with product teams, that actually the dysfunctional companies are all the same and then the happy companies or the higher performing companies can be very, very different.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: failure modes are repeatable anti-patterns, but success can be achieved through many different operating styles.

quotes.topic_title: What differentiates the highest-performing product teams
quotes.text: You meet lots of great teams and the better teams make high, better decisions faster.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A practical performance yardstick teams can operationalize by improving decision quality and cycle time.

quotes.topic_title: What differentiates the highest-performing product teams
quotes.text: So this is the thing, I'm sitting there and the very idealistic product managers are like, "You got to have empowered teams and you got to push decision-making down to the bottom," and I'm like, "Huh, well that company's doing pretty well and the CEO just tells everyone what to do and in fact, they attracted people who just don't mind that and like their vision and they do it."
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A contrarian observation that challenges the one-size-fits-all “empowered teams” doctrine by pointing to successful top-down decision models.

quotes.topic_title: What differentiates the highest-performing product teams
quotes.text: The first thing you notice is the companies that are very high performing have coherence between the structure of their company and their current strategy.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: An actionable diagnostic: align org/architecture/incentives with strategy to remove systemic drag even for strong teams.

quotes.topic_title: What differentiates the highest-performing product teams
quotes.text: I think the second thing, if I admit it, is the strong opinions loosely held, which is there is this balance of believing in certain things, believing maybe in the power of products or the power of connecting with customers or maybe key strategic things that they need to do, or even believing that this is a done deal and you just need to move faster than everyone else in the space, or even the belief that you need to just go straight to commodity pricing like Amazon with whatever you're doing.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A reusable operating principle for teams: commit to clear beliefs while staying adaptable as evidence changes.

quotes.topic_title: People vs environment: can teams become high-performing?
quotes.text: We know that you can have a bunch of geniuses in the room and if there's not coherent leadership and there's not coherent structure in what you're doing, they'll fail.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Highlights the limiting factor of talent without aligned leadership and system design—useful for diagnosing team underperformance.

quotes.topic_title: People vs environment: can teams become high-performing?
quotes.text: At a lot of companies that are known to be higher performing, they're one of two categories. Either everyone in the company is this extremely vetted genius at what they're doing, or they have a culture where people stay for three, four, five, six years, they build their career or seven, eight, nine years.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Offers a practical two-pattern model for how high-performing orgs are built: elite hiring vs long-tenure talent compounding.

quotes.topic_title: People vs environment: can teams become high-performing?
quotes.text: There is a concentration of people who are very skilled, but they have a knack for bringing people up. They have a knack for taking someone who has some of the raw materials to be able to do it and making them really good at their job to be able to do it.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Actionable emphasis on developing capability through coaching and growth systems, not just selecting for “A players.”

quotes.topic_title: People vs environment: can teams become high-performing?
quotes.text: Four or five years ago, I would've said, well, personal skill's nothing. It's all the environment.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A candid update that challenges single-cause explanations and encourages practitioners to balance talent and environment factors.

quotes.topic_title: People vs environment: can teams become high-performing?
quotes.text: High performance is not this state you achieve. It's actually a continuum that you're always ...
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for treating performance as ongoing practice rather than a permanent destination—useful for continuous improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals or can put your business on hold.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights SOC 2 as a practical go/no-go gate for revenue growth and deal velocity, especially with larger customers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you don't have a SOC 2, there's a good chance you won't even get a seat at the table.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that compliance can be a prerequisite for entering enterprise sales conversations at all.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But getting SOC 2 to your report can be a huge burden, especially for startups. It's time consuming, tedious and expensive.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames the operational tradeoff and resourcing reality teams should plan for when pursuing SOC 2.
